pageContext.claim: “I mean, you have hundreds of miles of open space, and they go out there, and they're loaded up with drugs or they have women in the backseat of the cars with duct tape all over the place. It's a disgrace. And you don't catch them. They make a -- you don't even know the difference between Mexico and the United States.”
pageContext.analysis: There are stretches of the U.S.-Mexico border that don't have a fence or wall, but it's misleading to suggest there is no security. In the areas without fencing, the rugged terrain around the river serves as a natural barrier. Plus, the U.S. uses a wide variety of blimps, balloons and drones to monitor the border. Plus, mentioning women trafficked with tape over their mouths has become a standard part of Trump’s talking points on the need for a border wall. But human-trafficking experts and advocates for immigrant women have said they are perplexed by this tale in Trump’s repertoire — and are at a loss for where he got his information. No prominent news reports have detailed a case that matches the president’s description.
